so ground truth is a way of building highly accurate data sets with some
built-in efficiencies for data labeling
and so let's talk about how this works so you've got your raw data and you
basically have to have a human annotate that data right so somebody's going to have to go in and provide labels to the
data and then what ground truth does
which is very very cool it it will use a semi-supervised tech
right so you can imagine let's say you have a large amount of data and a small amount of it was labeled you could build
a model from that small amount of labeled data that then can be used to label the rest of the data let's say
let's say it's object detection right so maybe you've got a model that you can build that says oh this is a piano and
that models reasonably accurate so now you can take a whole bunch of images and you can do inferences on those and say okay which ones have pianos and where is
it in the in the image right so that's that's why we call it a semi supervised technique because you are starting with
a small amount of actual supervised labelled data and then you're you're using using that to automate the process
you have to be careful with this because if there's a bias in the original data that you've labeled that bias will show
up in the model and of course accuracy is important right you wouldn't want to automatically label something where
where the the models labeling it with low accuracy so what we've what we've added to account for that is that
there's this human step here too so you can if you again it's one of these things where if you if you have a
confidence threshold that you're comfortable with for automatically labeling data saige maker ground truth
will go ahead and just automatically label it but anything that doesn't meet that confidence threshold can go to a human for actual human labeling and what
you end up with at the end of this is labeled training data so the idea here
